message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on post-translational modifications for help. The attachment of a chemically-tagged protein to lysine residues suggests ubiquitination, which marks proteins for degradation by the proteasome. Glycosylation attaches sugar molecules, phosphorylation adds phosphate groups, and carboxylation adds carboxyl groups to amino acids on a polypeptide chain. None of these processes involve the attachment of a chemically-tagged protein to lysine residues.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on protein modification for help. The chemically-tagged protein attaching covalently to lysine residues suggests that the modification is ubiquitination, which marks proteins for degradation. Glycosylation, phosphorylation, and carboxylation do not involve chemical tagging with another protein.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options provided, only ubiquitination involves attaching a chemically-tagged protein to a lysine residue on a polypeptide chain. This modification results in the targeting of the modified protein for degradation by the proteasome. The addition of the barrel-shaped complex in this scenario represents the proteasome. Therefore, the correct answer is (D) ubiquitination.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on post-translational modification for help. Among the options, only ubiquitination involves the covalent attachment of a protein to lysine residues on the polypeptide chain, leading to the degradation of the modified polypeptide into individual amino acids and the chemically-tagged proteins.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on post-translational modifications for help. The chemically-tagged protein that attaches to the lysine residues in the polypeptide chain suggests that ubiquitination has occurred. This modification targets proteins for degradation by the proteasome. Glycosylation involves the attachment of carbohydrate molecules, phosphorylation involves the addition of phosphate groups, and carboxylation involves the addition of a carboxyl group. None of these modifications involve the attachment of a chemically-tagged protein to lysine residues.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The modification described involves covalent attachment to lysine residues, which is characteristic of ubiquitination. Glycosylation involves attachment of sugar molecules, phosphorylation involves attachment of a phosphate group, and carboxylation involves addition of a carboxyl group to specific amino acids.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on biochemistry for help. The question describes a process called ubiquitination, in which a chemically-tagged protein attaches to lysine residues on a polypeptide chain. Upon the addition of a barrel-shaped protein complex, the modified polypeptide lyses into individual amino acids and tagged proteins. Glycosylation, phosphorylation, and carboxylation do not involve the covalent attachment of a protein tag to a polypeptide chain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on biochemistry for help. The chemically-tagged protein indicates that the modification is through ubiquitination, where ubiquitin is covalently attached to lysine residues on the polypeptide chain. Glycosylation adds a carbohydrate group, phosphorylation adds a phosphate group, and carboxylation adds a carboxyl group, none of which involve the attachment of a chemically-tagged protein that results in lysing of the modified polypeptide.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on biochemistry for help. The chemically-tagged protein attaching covalently to lysine residues and the subsequent lysis of the modified polypeptide suggest that ubiquitination has occurred. Glycosylation involves the addition of carbohydrate molecules, phosphorylation involves the addition of a phosphate group, and carboxylation involves the addition of a carboxyl group, but none of these processes involve the lysis of the polypeptide.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The post-translational modification described in the question involves covalent attachment of a chemically-tagged protein to lysine residues on the polypeptide chain, followed by lysis of the modified polypeptide into individual amino acids and tagged proteins. This is consistent with ubiquitination, which involves attachment of ubiquitin molecules to lysine residues on a protein, leading to proteasomal degradation of the tagged protein. Glycosylation involves covalent attachment of carbohydrate molecules to proteins, phosphorylation involves addition of a phosphate group to specific amino acid residues, and carboxylation involves addition of a carboxyl group to specific amino acid residues.
